jacques-n commented on issue #5973: ARROW-7329: [Java] AllocationManager: Allow managing different types …
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5973#issuecomment-562141625
 
 
   Nice work. Can you make a change so that allocationmanager is the base class and NettyAllocationManager is the subclass? Will make this much easier to review and track history.

zhztheplayer commented on issue #5973: ARROW-7329: [Java] AllocationManager: Allow managing different types …
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5973#issuecomment-562156467
 
 
   @jacques-n - Sure, will do. I was to avoid breaking change to AllocationManager, but I see we have  commented:
   https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/6cfe3e08a4c0100716e3f34325a113bffb2f47a1/java/memory/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/memory/AllocationManager.java#L36-L38
   So actually I am not sure if it's necessary to preserve the class name. Thanks for your suggestion.

zhztheplayer commented on pull request #5973: ARROW-7329: [Java] AllocationManager: Allow managing different types …
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5973#discussion_r354729754
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/memory/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/memory/AllocationManager.java
 ##########
 @@ -172,10 +154,10 @@ void release(final BufferLedger ledger) {
         // the only <allocator, reference manager> mapping was for the owner
         // which now has been removed, it implies we can safely destroy the
         // underlying memory chunk as it is no longer being referenced
-        ((BaseAllocator)oldLedger.getAllocator()).releaseBytes(size);
+        ((BaseAllocator)oldLedger.getAllocator()).releaseBytes(getSize());
 
 Review comment:
   This is to keep up with the current behaviour. Following is the constructor code of current `AllocationManager`:
   https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/21a4ffe7411ac62c97d636a478481d96c26380a3/java/memory/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/memory/AllocationManager.java#L73-L84
   
   This allows an AllocationManager allocates different bytes of memory comparing to desired. So at here, `size` is desired size passed by constructor, while `getSize()` should be the actual size. I'll do some name changes in case of confusing.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

   I was thinking to force the implementations to be packaged under `org.apache.arrow.memory`... Which doesn't seem to be necessary.

zhztheplayer commented on pull request #5973: ARROW-7329: [Java] AllocationManager: Allow managing different types …
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5973#discussion_r354741119
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/memory/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/memory/AllocationManager.java
 ##########
 @@ -47,22 +43,17 @@
  * typical query. The
  * contention of acquiring a lock on AllocationManager should be very low.
  */
-public class AllocationManager {
+public abstract class AllocationManager {
 
 Review comment:
   Thanks! It's reasonable but AllocationManager's constructor requires an `BaseAllocator` instance as a parameter, as a result, passing a AllocationManager factory to BufferAllocator's constructor brings dependency cycle (chicken & egg). Should we try decouple `BaseAllocator` from AllocationManager's constructor?
   
   And probably I am not able to correctly getting this:
   > rather than making this abstract, ...
   
   Does this mean we should keep the `public class AllocationManager`, and make it extend a base class? Like what's in my first version?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

users@infra.apache.org

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
This is related to an unfinished part[1] in the fix of ARROW-4714.

And this is more or less related to ARROW-7272. Buffers in VectorSchemaRoot converted from arrow::RecordBatch should be managed by Java-side buffer allocators.

[1] https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4348/files#diff-2c2d410f62740cf71f70127f5888f6edR84
fields.summary: [Java] AllocationManager: Allow managing different types of memory other than those are allocated using Netty
